sections.title: Introduction/Background
sections.tldr: Escherichia coli is the most widely used host for recombinant protein production due to its well-established genetics, low cost, and rapid growth. Despite its popularity, producers face significant challenges including protein folding issues, metabolic limitations, and lack of post-translational modifications. (12 sources)
sections.text:
Escherichia coli has emerged as the organism of choice for the production of recombinant proteins in both academic research and industrial applications due to its well-characterized genetics, ease of genetic manipulation, rapid growth, and low manufacturing costs <Paper corpusId="1585460" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15197002" paperTitle="(Jia et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. The extensive use of E. coli as an expression platform has led to the development of numerous molecular tools and protocols for high-level protein production, including a vast catalog of expression plasmids, engineered strains, and cultivation strategies <Paper corpusId="1585460" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advantages, the production of recombinant proteins in E. coli is often accompanied by significant challenges that can transform what should be a straightforward procedure into a time-consuming and frustrating experience <Paper corpusId="112829" paperTitle="(Schumann et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>. One of the most common issues is the formation of inclusion bodies, which are insoluble aggregates of misfolded proteins that form when the cell's protein folding machinery becomes overwhelmed by high expression levels <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>. This problem is particularly prevalent when expressing heterologous proteins due to differences in folding pathways between the expression and natural hosts <Paper corpusId="49864461" paperTitle="(Sheli et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Other significant challenges include codon bias issues, metabolic burden on the host cells, absence of post-translational modifications (such as glycosylation), protein solubility problems, and inefficient secretion <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15197002" paperTitle="(Jia et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Industrial-scale production brings additional concerns related to reducing production costs while maintaining protein quality and improving both upstream and downstream productivity <Paper corpusId="233902859" paperTitle="(Mulyanti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The field has evolved from a largely empirical approach to a more rational design-based methodology, with ongoing efforts to overcome these challenges through genetic engineering, synthetic biology, and process optimization <Paper corpusId="233868127" paperTitle="(Tungekar et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15197002" paperTitle="(Jia et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Novel approaches include the development of self-inducible expression systems to replace costly and potentially toxic inducers like IPTG <Paper corpusId="233902859" paperTitle="(Mulyanti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="3385557" paperTitle="(Briand et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>, strategies for extracellular protein production to avoid periplasmic proteolysis <Paper corpusId="263441247" paperTitle="(2006)" isShortName></Paper>, and co-expression of chaperones to enhance proper protein folding <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="7025152" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: Escherichia coli is by far the most widely used host for the production of recombinant proteins. There are many protocols, a great number of expression plasmids, and engineered strains that can be used to obtain high protein yields (Rosano et al., 2014). Despite numerous advantages, biotechnological potential of E. coli also has its limitations including the risk of protein aggregation and accumulation of acetate as by-product. Upon high-level production, recombinant proteins may aggregate and form inclusion bodies (IBs) in E. coli cells. Formation of IBs is a complex and dynamic process affected by various factors involving molecular chaperones that control protein folding. The vast increase in misfolded recombinant proteins exhausts the capacity of molecular chaperones leading to the formation of IBs (Schlieker et al., 2002)(Marco et al., 2007). To recover biologically active proteins from IBs, additional steps in purification procedure such as solubilization of IBs and subsequent refolding of desired proteins are required. Coexpression of molecular chaperones or lower production rate can prevent aggregation and facilitate the proper folding of recombinant proteins (Rosano et al., 2014)(Schlieker et al., 2002)(Marco et al., 2007).

snippets: BackgroundThe overproduction of recombinant proteins in host cells often leads to their misfolding and aggregation. Previous attempts to increase the solubility of recombinant proteins by co-overproduction of individual chaperones were only partially successful. We now assessed the effects of combined overproduction of the functionally cooperating chaperone network of the E. coli cytosol on the solubility of recombinant proteins.ResultsA two-step procedure was found to show the strongest enhancement of solubility. paper.title: So you want to express your protein in Escherichia coli?

snippets: Recombinant proteins have been extensively employed as therapeutics for the treatment of various critical and life-threatening diseases and as industrial enzymes in high-value industrial processes. Advances in genetic engineering and synthetic biology have broadened the horizon of heterologous protein production using multiple expression platforms. Selection of a suitable expression system depends on a variety of factors ranging from the physicochemical properties of the target protein to economic considerations. For more than 40 years, Escherichia coli has been an established organism of choice for protein production. This review aims to provide a stepwise approach for any researcher embarking on the journey of recombinant protein production in E. coli. We present an overview of the challenges associated with heterologous protein expression, fundamental considerations connected to the protein of interest (POI) and designing expression constructs, as well as insights into recently developed technologies that have contributed to this ever-growing field.

paper.title: A self-inducible heterologous protein expression system in Escherichia coli

snippets: Escherichia coli is an important experimental, medical and industrial cell factory for recombinant protein production. The inducible lac promoter is one of the most commonly used promoters for heterologous protein expression in E. coli. Isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactoside (IPTG) is currently the most efficient molecular inducer for regulating this promoter’s transcriptional activity. However, limitations have been observed in large-scale and microplate production, including toxicity, cost and culture monitoring. Here, we report the novel SILEX (Self-InducibLe Expression) system, which is a convenient, cost-effective alternative that does not require cell density monitoring or IPTG induction. We demonstrate the broad utility of the presented self-inducible method for a panel of diverse proteins produced in large amounts. The SILEX system is compatible with all classical culture media and growth temperatures and allows protein expression modulation. Importantly, the SILEX system is proven to be efficient for protein expression screening on a microplate scale.

sections.title: Protein Folding and Inclusion Body Formation
sections.tldr: Protein misfolding and inclusion body formation represent major challenges in recombinant protein production in E. coli, often resulting when the cell's protein folding machinery becomes overwhelmed. sections.text:
One of the most significant challenges in recombinant protein production in E. coli is the formation of inclusion bodies (IBs), which are insoluble aggregates of misfolded proteins <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231858555" paperTitle="(Bhatwa et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. These aggregates form primarily because the overexpression of heterologous proteins overwhelms the cell's native protein folding machinery, leading to protein misfolding and aggregation <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that up to 75% of human proteins can be expressed in E. coli, but only about 25% are produced in an active soluble form <Paper corpusId="7564064" paperTitle="(Costa et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

The formation of inclusion bodies results from several interrelated factors. First, the high concentration of nascent polypeptide chains in recombinant cells promotes aggregation reactions at the expense of proper folding <Paper corpusId="234052080" paperTitle="(Vincenti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Second, the rapid rate of coupled transcription and translation in bacteria can be problematic for large eukaryotic proteins that require more time to fold correctly <Paper corpusId="268152870" paperTitle="(McNutt et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="31546198" paperTitle="(Francis et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, the absence of appropriate folding-assistance proteins and cofactors in E. coli that are present in the protein's natural host further complicates proper folding <Paper corpusId="7025152" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

Inclusion bodies pose significant downstream challenges as they require additional processing steps to recover biologically active proteins. This typically involves solubilization using denaturing agents followed by complex refolding procedures <Paper corpusId="231819880" paperTitle="(Javadian et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="24807019" paperTitle="(Singh et al., 2005)" isShortName></Paper>. These additional steps are often time-consuming, labor-intensive, and may result in poor recovery of bioactive proteins, significantly increasing production costs <Paper corpusId="264402351" paperTitle="(Abdolvahab et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The severity of protein folding issues is often determined by specific properties of the recombinant protein and the rates of transcription and translation <Paper corpusId="262692133" paperTitle="(Gasser et al., 2008)" isShortName></Paper>. Heterologous protein production can account for up to 50% of E. coli's total cellular protein content, placing significant strain on the native transcriptional and translational machinery <Paper corpusId="268152870" paperTitle="(McNutt et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="1585460" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

Several strategies have been developed to address these challenges, including coexpression of molecular chaperones, reducing production rates, and modifying culture conditions <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264402351" paperTitle="(Abdolvahab et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. However, these approaches have met with mixed and largely unpredictable results <Paper corpusId="15379654" paperTitle="(Kolaj et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. Strain selection, expression vector choice, and optimization of induction conditions (timing, inducer concentration, temperature, and duration) are also critical factors that can significantly affect protein solubility <Paper corpusId="234052080" paperTitle="(Vincenti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264402351" paperTitle="(Abdolvahab et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Codon optimization strategies can enhance soluble protein production but sometimes impair protein folding and decrease activity <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10726877" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="16261433" paperTitle="(Gvritishvili et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Interestingly, synonymous codon usage without altering amino acid sequences can significantly affect protein properties, including solubility and functionality <Paper corpusId="28285896" paperTitle="(Hu et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

The challenges of protein folding and inclusion body formation remain major bottlenecks in the field of recombinant protein production in E. coli <Paper corpusId="7564064" paperTitle="(Costa et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="85571730" paperTitle="(O'Dwyer et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>, necessitating ongoing development of improved expression strategies and host systems.

paper.title: Solubilization and refolding of bacterial inclusion body proteins.

snippets: Inclusion bodies produced in Escherichia coli are composed of densely packed denatured protein molecules in the form of particles. Refolding of inclusion body proteins into bioactive forms is cumbersome, results in poor recovery and accounts for the major cost in production of recombinant proteins from E. coli. With new information available on the structure and function of protein aggregates in bacterial inclusion bodies, it has been possible to develop improved solubilization and refolding procedures for higher recovery of bioactive protein. Inclusion bodies are formed from partially folded protein intermediates and are composed of aggregates of mostly single types of polypeptide. This helps to isolate and purify the protein aggregates to homogeneity before solubilization and refolding. Proteins inside inclusion body aggregates have native-like secondary structures. It is assumed that restoration of this native-like secondary structure using mild solubilization conditions will help in improved recovery of bioactive protein in comparison to solubilization using a high concentration of chaotropic agent. Analysis of the dominant forces causing aggregation during inclusion body formation provides information to develop suitable mild solubilization procedures for inclusion body proteins. Refolding from such solubilized protein will be very high due to restoration of native-like secondary structure. Human growth hormone inclusion bodies were purified to homogeneity from E. coli cells before solubilization and refolding. Pure inclusion bodies were solubilized at alkaline pH in the presence of 2 M urea solution. The solubilized proteins were refolded using a pulsatile renaturation process and subsequently purified using chromatographic procedures. More than 40% of the inclusion body proteins could be refolded back to the bioactive native conformation. Mild solubilization is thus the key for high recovery of bioactive protein from inclusion bodies.

paper.title: Rare codon content affects the solubility of recombinant proteins in a codon bias-adjusted Escherichia coli strain

snippets: BackgroundThe expression of heterologous proteins in Escherichia coli is strongly affected by codon bias. This phenomenon occurs when the codon usage of the mRNA coding for the foreign protein differs from that of the bacterium. The ribosome pauses upon encountering a rare codon and may detach from the mRNA, thereby the yield of protein expression is reduced. Several bacterial strains have been engineered to overcome this effect. However, the increased rate of translation may lead to protein misfolding and insolubilization. In order to prove this assumption, the solubility of several recombinant proteins from plants was studied in a codon bias-adjusted E. coli strain.ResultsThe expression of eight plant proteins in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3)-pLysS and BL21(DE3)-CodonPlus-pRIL was systematically studied. The CodonPlus strain contains extra copies of the argU, ileY, and leuW tRNA genes, which encode tRNAs that recognize the codons AGA/AGG, AUA and CUA, respectively (RIL codons). The level of expression and solubility of the recombinant proteins were analyzed by means of sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blotting. We found that for all proteins the solubility was at least 25% in the BL21(DE3)-pLysS strain. However, when expressed in the BL21(DE3)-CodonPlus-pRIL strain, proteins having more than 5% of amino acids coded by RIL codons were localized mainly in the insoluble fraction. sections.title: Metabolic and Physiological Limitations
sections.tldr: Recombinant protein production imposes significant metabolic burden on E. coli cells, leading to reduced growth rates, plasmid instability, and accumulation of toxic byproducts like acetate. Environmental factors such as oxygen limitation also impact cell physiology and protein quality, making process optimization critical for maintaining productivity. (8 sources)
sections.text:
The production of recombinant proteins places considerable metabolic stress on E. coli host cells, often referred to as "metabolic burden" or "metabolic load" <Paper corpusId="270094117" paperTitle="(Rajacharya et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This burden can significantly reduce the host bacteria's growth rate and lead to plasmid instability when using episomal expression systems <Paper corpusId="261056204" paperTitle="(Jahromi et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. The stress is particularly pronounced when proteins are overexpressed under strong promoters such as T7, which can overwhelm cellular resources and often results in inclusion body formation <Paper corpusId="261056204" paperTitle="(Jahromi et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

One of the major physiological limitations in high-density E. coli cultures is overflow metabolism, which leads to acetate accumulation. This byproduct becomes toxic at higher concentrations, further inhibiting cell growth and protein production <Paper corpusId="237677625" paperTitle="(Mitchell et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. The traditional batch cultivation method used in many research laboratories exacerbates these metabolic issues compared to the fed-batch approaches commonly employed in industrial settings <Paper corpusId="16010334" paperTitle="(Krause et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

Environmental factors during cultivation also significantly impact the physiological state of the cells and subsequently affect protein production. Process robustness studies have shown that soluble protein production is particularly sensitive to environmental fluctuations <Paper corpusId="231695527" paperTitle="(Pekarsky et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Technical failures that lead to oxygen limitation can dramatically alter cell physiology, productivity, and protein quality <Paper corpusId="231695527" paperTitle="(Pekarsky et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. When E. coli cells are grown under industrial conditions, they often experience harsh environments that can deteriorate their physiological state, further reducing production efficiency <Paper corpusId="7564064" paperTitle="(Costa et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

The metabolic challenges are compounded when producing complex proteins, as the vast increase in misfolded recombinant proteins exhausts the capacity of molecular chaperones <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>. This overloading of the cellular protein quality control system creates a cascade effect where resources are diverted to deal with misfolded proteins rather than supporting growth and maintenance.

To address these metabolic limitations, controlled feeding strategies like fed-batch cultivation can significantly improve both cell yields and protein folding by maintaining lower, more manageable growth rates <Paper corpusId="16010334" paperTitle="(Krause et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Alternative approaches include genomic integration of the target gene to reduce copy number and associated metabolic burden <Paper corpusId="261056204" paperTitle="(Jahromi et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>, though this typically results in lower expression levels compared to plasmid-based systems.

sections.title: Codon Usage and Translation Issues
sections.tldr: Codon bias between E. coli and heterologous genes significantly impacts protein expression efficiency, as rare codons can cause ribosomal pausing and reduced yields. Attempts to overcome this through codon optimization or tRNA supplementation often succeed in improving expression but can paradoxically lead to protein misfolding and reduced solubility. (8 sources)
sections.text:
Codon usage represents a significant challenge in recombinant protein production in E. coli, particularly when expressing heterologous genes with codon preferences that differ from the host organism <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. The presence of "rare" codons in the target gene can adversely affect protein expression levels, as E. coli has limited tRNA availability for these codons <Paper corpusId="237220817" paperTitle="(Makrides, 1996)" isShortName></Paper>. Specifically, the tRNA levels for rare codons such as AGG, AGA, AUA, CCC, CUA, and GGA often restrain high-level production of recombinant proteins <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

When E. coli ribosomes encounter these rare codons during translation, they may pause or even detach from the mRNA, resulting in reduced expression yields or incomplete protein synthesis <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10726877" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. This problem is particularly pronounced when the rare codons appear in clusters or at critical positions within the coding sequence <Paper corpusId="237220817" paperTitle="(Makrides, 1996)" isShortName></Paper>.

Two main strategies have been developed to address codon usage issues: codon optimization and tRNA supplementation. Codon optimization involves redesigning the gene sequence to use E. coli's preferred codons without changing the amino acid sequence <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach has been shown to enhance protein expression levels, with some studies reporting up to 3-4 fold increases in yield <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="16261433" paperTitle="(Gvritishvili et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

The alternative approach involves using E. coli strains supplemented with extra copies of tRNA genes that recognize rare codons, such as BL21(DE3)-CodonPlus-pRIL, which contains additional tRNAs for recognizing AGA/AGG, AUA, and CUA codons <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10726877" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. While this strategy can increase overall expression levels, it doesn't always translate to improved functional protein yield.

Interestingly, both approaches present an unexpected challenge: they can sometimes impair protein folding and decrease biological activity <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. Research has shown that proteins with high content of rare codons (more than 5% of amino acids coded by rare codons) expressed in codon bias-adjusted strains tend to localize mainly in the insoluble fraction <Paper corpusId="10726877" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. This phenomenon supports the hypothesis that elimination of translational pauses increases the translation rate but can lead to protein misfolding and aggregation, as the nascent polypeptide chain doesn't have sufficient time to fold properly <Paper corpusId="10726877" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent studies have further demonstrated that synonymous codons can significantly alter protein properties without changing the amino acid sequence <Paper corpusId="28285896" paperTitle="(Hu et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. In one experiment, 342 antibody codon variants with identical amino acid sequences showed dramatic differences in solubility and functionality, ranging from completely insoluble aggregates to properly folded proteins with high binding affinity <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="28285896" paperTitle="(Hu et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

These findings highlight the complex relationship between codon usage, translation rate, and protein folding, suggesting that obtaining well-folded recombinant proteins with high yield remains a major challenge in E. coli expression systems <Paper corpusId="4579748" paperTitle="(Fang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15197002" paperTitle="(Jia et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. As a result, the field is moving from trial-and-error approaches toward more rational design strategies that consider not only codon optimization but also the impact of translation kinetics on protein folding <Paper corpusId="15197002" paperTitle="(Jia et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="254248171" paperTitle="(Du et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

sections.title: Lack of Post-Translational Modifications
sections.tldr: E. coli lacks the cellular machinery to perform many eukaryotic post-translational modifications, particularly glycosylation and proper disulfide bond formation, which significantly limits its ability to produce complex functional proteins. This limitation often results in improperly folded proteins with reduced biological activity, necessitating the development of engineered strains and alternative expression strategies. (10 sources)
sections.text:
Despite being the most widely used expression system for recombinant protein production, E. coli's inability to perform several key post-translational modifications represents a major challenge, especially when expressing complex eukaryotic proteins <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="254248171" paperTitle="(Du et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. The bacterial host lacks sophisticated machinery for modifications such as glycosylation, cytosolic disulfide bond formation, and proteolytic protein maturation, which are often essential for the proper folding and function of many mammalian proteins <Paper corpusId="268523497" paperTitle="(Koppl et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="1213904" paperTitle="(Kamionka, 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

The absence of these modifications frequently leads to expression problems, including poor solubility and the formation of inclusion bodies, as proteins requiring these modifications for proper folding cannot achieve their native conformation in the E. coli cytoplasm <Paper corpusId="31546198" paperTitle="(Francis et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. This limitation is particularly problematic for complex proteins where post-translational modifications are integral to their structure and biological activity <Paper corpusId="7564064" paperTitle="(Costa et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have reported that while up to 75% of human proteins can be expressed in E. coli, only about 25% are produced in an active soluble form, largely due to these missing modification capabilities <Paper corpusId="7564064" paperTitle="(Costa et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

The highly reductive environment of the bacterial cytosol further complicates the formation of disulfide bonds, which are critical for the stability and activity of many secreted and membrane proteins <Paper corpusId="31546198" paperTitle="(Francis et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. While some specialized E. coli strains have been engineered to enable cytosolic disulfide bond formation, such as the SHuffle and Origami hosts, these solutions are not universally effective for all proteins <Paper corpusId="268523497" paperTitle="(Koppl et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="2161676" paperTitle="(Lobstein et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

To circumvent these limitations, researchers have developed various strategies, including designing specialized plasmids, optimizing culture conditions, and co-expressing target proteins with molecular chaperones <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="254248171" paperTitle="(Du et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="265478111" paperTitle="(Arrolla et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Protein engineering approaches have also been employed to modify protein features and improve stability in the absence of natural post-translational modifications <Paper corpusId="1213904" paperTitle="(Kamionka, 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advancements, the lack of post-translational modifications continues to be a significant bottleneck in recombinant protein production in E. coli, especially for complex eukaryotic proteins where these modifications are essential for proper folding and biological activity <Paper corpusId="73620977" paperTitle="(Jamrichova et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264615304" paperTitle="(Ferrer-Miralles et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: BackgroundProduction of correctly disulfide bonded proteins to high yields remains a challenge. Recombinant protein expression in Escherichia coli is the popular choice, especially within the research community. While there is an ever growing demand for new expression strains, few strains are dedicated to post-translational modifications, such as disulfide bond formation. Thus, new protein expression strains must be engineered and the parameters involved in producing disulfide bonded proteins must be understood.ResultsWe have engineered a new E. coli protein expression strain named SHuffle, dedicated to producing correctly disulfide bonded active proteins to high yields within its cytoplasm. sections.text:
The challenges associated with recombinant protein production in E. coli have led researchers to develop various strategies to improve expression yields and protein functionality:

1. **Optimization of culture conditions** - Adjusting parameters such as temperature, inducer concentration, timing of induction, and duration significantly impacts protein solubility. Lower cultivation temperatures (typically 19-25°C) often reduce inclusion body formation by slowing protein synthesis and allowing more time for proper folding <Paper corpusId="264402351" paperTitle="(Abdolvahab et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="233674494" paperTitle="(Iftikhar, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

2. **Fed-batch cultivation** - This approach provides a controlled nutrient supply that maintains lower growth rates, reducing metabolic burden and improving protein folding compared to traditional batch cultures <Paper corpusId="16010334" paperTitle="(Krause et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

3. **Co-expression of molecular chaperones** - Overproduction of chaperone systems (GroEL/GroES, DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE, ClpB, and IbpA/IbpB) helps overcome protein folding limitations by assisting in de novo folding and refolding of misfolded proteins <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="254248171" paperTitle="(Du et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

4. **Two-step expression protocol** - A novel approach involves first co-expressing chaperones with the target protein, then inhibiting protein synthesis to allow chaperone-mediated refolding of misfolded proteins, which has increased solubility up to 42-fold for various proteins <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>.

5. **Fusion protein technology** - Using solubility-enhancing fusion partners improves protein folding, solubility, protection from proteases, and facilitates detection and purification <Paper corpusId="237220817" paperTitle="(Makrides, 1996)" isShortName></Paper>.

6. **Codon optimization** - Addressing the issue of rare codons through gene sequence modification or using specialized strains containing supplementary tRNAs for rare codons <Paper corpusId="237220817" paperTitle="(Makrides, 1996)" isShortName></Paper>.

7. **Extracellular production** - Directing proteins to the extracellular environment avoids periplasmic proteolysis and allows continuous production <Paper corpusId="263441247" paperTitle="(2006)" isShortName></Paper>.

8. **Specialized strains for disulfide bond formation** - Engineered strains such as SHuffle and Origami enable cytosolic disulfide bond formation, addressing a major limitation in E. coli expression <Paper corpusId="268523497" paperTitle="(Koppl et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="2161676" paperTitle="(Lobstein et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

9. **Genomic integration** - Integration of heterologous genes into the E. coli chromosome can reduce metabolic burden and plasmid instability, though typically with lower expression levels <Paper corpusId="261056204" paperTitle="(Jahromi et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

10. **Protease-deficient host strains** - Using strains with reduced protease activity minimizes proteolytic degradation of recombinant proteins <Paper corpusId="237220817" paperTitle="(Makrides, 1996)" isShortName></Paper>.

11. **Optimization through statistical design** - Response Surface Methodology (RSM) and other statistical approaches enable systematic optimization of multiple expression parameters simultaneously <Paper corpusId="262236762" paperTitle="(Katalani et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advances, optimization of protein expression in E. coli often remains a process of trial and error, with unpredictable results for different target proteins <Paper corpusId="15379654" paperTitle="(Kolaj et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6670707" paperTitle="(Makino et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. The effectiveness of these strategies varies significantly depending on the specific properties of the target protein, requiring customized approaches for different proteins <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: Escherichia coli is by far the most widely used host for the production of recombinant proteins. Upon high-level production, recombinant proteins may aggregate and form inclusion bodies (IBs) in E. coli cells. snippets: BackgroundThe overproduction of recombinant proteins in host cells often leads to their misfolding and aggregation. Previous attempts to increase the solubility of recombinant proteins by co-overproduction of individual chaperones were only partially successful. We now assessed the effects of combined overproduction of the functionally cooperating chaperone network of the E. coli cytosol on the solubility of recombinant proteins.ResultsA two-step procedure was found to show the strongest enhancement of solubility. In a first step, the four chaperone systems GroEL/GroES, DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE, ClpB and the small HSPs IbpA/IbpB, were coordinately co-overproduced with recombinant proteins to optimize de novo folding. In a second step, protein biosynthesis was inhibited to permit chaperone mediated refolding of misfolded and aggregated proteins in vivo. This novel strategy increased the solubility of 70% of 64 different heterologous proteins tested up to 42-fold.ConclusionThe engineered E. coli strains and the two-step procedure presented here led to a remarkable increase in the solubility of a various recombinant proteins and should be applicable to a wide range of target proteins produced in biotechnology.

The most common and successful expression method of recombinant proteins is episomal expression. However, this method has some apparent weaknesses.

The metabolic load caused by the plasmid can lead to the reduction of the host bacteria's growth and instability of the plasmid encoding the recombinant gene (17).

On the other hand, overexpression under strong promoters such as T7 may, in many cases, lead to the formation of IBs that are sometimes difficult to refold. Although these intracellular bodies may protect the heterologous protein from the damage of cellular proteases and are also useful in the initial stages of protein purification, refolding some proteins is a serious challenge. This can increase the cost of the final product (18) and is documented in the case of human growth hormone. When this hormone was expressed in E. coli at 37°C, almost all the expressed protein was in the form of IB (19). Therefore, reducing or preventing the formation of IBs can facilitate the purification process of some proteins, including human growth hormones.

The instability of the recombinant plasmid and the metabolic load caused by the high copy number of the plasmid may be solved or reduced by integrating the heterologous gene in the appropriate position of the host genome (20).

snippets: Avian necrotic enteritis (NE) is a multi-virulence disease caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. Several toxins of this bacteria are components of different candidate vaccines, and have been considered as important factors in pathogenesis of NE. A fusion subunit protein composed of immunodominant segments of NetB, Alpha-toxin and metallopeptidase proteins (NAM) was designed. The high level production of NE subunit vaccine candidate is important for the in vitro and in vivo evaluation and later to decrease the production costs. Therefore, the Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was used for optimizing E. coli culture condition. To this end, induction conditions including cell optical density prior induction (OD600nm), IPTG concentration, post-induction temperature and time were modified. A 7.39 fold increase in production of soluble rNAM was achieved when the post induction temperature, IPTG concentration, the pre-induction OD and time were 19 oC, 0.55 mM, 0.8 respectively in 8 h after induction. sections.text:
Despite its widespread use as a protein production host, E. coli presents significant challenges related to protein secretion and localization. A major limitation is the bacterium's poor natural ability to secrete proteins, which contributes to several downstream issues including inclusion body formation, low production titers, and more complex purification procedures <Paper corpusId="248088013" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Researchers often target recombinant protein production to the periplasmic space of E. coli for several important advantages compared to cytoplasmic expression. The periplasm enables disulfide bond formation, facilitates protein isolation, allows control over the N-terminus of mature proteins, and can reduce exposure to cytoplasmic proteases. However, periplasmic expression comes with its own set of challenges, including problems with protein targeting, translocation difficulties, protein folding issues, and stability concerns that can significantly reduce overall yields <Paper corpusId="245125863" paperTitle="(Karyolaimos et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Extracellular production represents an alternative approach that offers distinct advantages over both cytoplasmic and periplasmic expression. By secreting proteins into the culture medium, producers can avoid the need for outer membrane disruption to recover target proteins, bypass issues with periplasmic proteases, and potentially establish continuous production processes. This approach eliminates several bottlenecks associated with intracellular accumulation but requires specific strategies to overcome E. coli's inherent secretion limitations <Paper corpusId="263441247" paperTitle="(2006)" isShortName></Paper>.

The challenges of protein secretion and localization in E. coli remain significant hurdles in recombinant protein production, necessitating the development of specialized strategies to enhance secretion efficiency and maintain protein quality. These limitations have motivated ongoing research into alternative secretion pathways, engineered signal sequences, and novel host strains with improved secretion capabilities.

sections.text:
The transition from laboratory-scale protein expression to industrial production presents numerous challenges for E. coli-based systems. A fundamental disconnect exists between typical research practices and industrial production methods, as most molecular biology laboratories use simple batch cultures while industry relies on nutrient-limited fed-batch technology <Paper corpusId="16010334" paperTitle="(Krause et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This difference in cultivation strategy can significantly impact protein folding and yield, as controlled nutrient feeding in fed-batch processes enables lower growth rates that often improve protein folding <Paper corpusId="16010334" paperTitle="(Krause et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

When scaling up to industrial production, bacterial strain stability becomes a critical concern. Genetic instabilities in both the bacterial strains and recombinant plasmids lead to increased cell heterogeneity during large-scale fermentation, directly impacting protein yield and quality <Paper corpusId="237677625" paperTitle="(Mitchell et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. High-density cultures face additional challenges such as inclusion body formation and acetate toxicity through overflow metabolism, which can severely limit productivity <Paper corpusId="237677625" paperTitle="(Mitchell et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The economic aspects of large-scale production create additional constraints, as manufacturers must balance production costs with maintaining protein quality <Paper corpusId="233902859" paperTitle="(Mulyanti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. The use of costly inducers like IPTG in traditional expression systems introduces both economic and toxicity concerns <Paper corpusId="233902859" paperTitle="(Mulyanti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="3385557" paperTitle="(Briand et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This has driven research into alternative induction systems and self-inducible expression methods that eliminate the need for expensive chemical inducers <Paper corpusId="233902859" paperTitle="(Mulyanti et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: A self-inducible heterologous protein expression system in Escherichia coli

snippets: Escherichia coli is an important experimental, medical and industrial cell factory for recombinant protein production. The inducible lac promoter is one of the most commonly used promoters for heterologous protein expression in E. coli. Isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactoside (IPTG) is currently the most efficient molecular inducer for regulating this promoter’s transcriptional activity. However, limitations have been observed in large-scale and microplate production, including toxicity, cost and culture monitoring. Here, we report the novel SILEX (Self-InducibLe Expression) system, which is a convenient, cost-effective alternative that does not require cell density monitoring or IPTG induction. We demonstrate the broad utility of the presented self-inducible method for a panel of diverse proteins produced in large amounts. The SILEX system is compatible with all classical culture media and growth temperatures and allows protein expression modulation. Importantly, the SILEX system is proven to be efficient for protein expression screening on a microplate scale.
